{|td align=right border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=5> |} {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0 0 1em 1em; width: 23em;" |- style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background-color: {{{Color|LightSteelBlue}}};" | [[Colorado Buffaloes football|Colorado Buffaloes]] - [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska Cornhuskers]] |- | colspan="2" style="text-align: center" | [[File:Colorado Buffaloes alternate logo.gif|80px|Colorado logo]]    [[Image:University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg|80px|Nebraska logo]] |- ! style="background: #E0E7EF;" colspan="2" | History |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''First Meeting''' || November 17, 1898 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Last Meeting''' || November 26, 2010 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Next Meeting''' || None Scheduled |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Number of Meetings''' || 69 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''All-Time Series''' || Nebraska: 49â18â2 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Largest victory''' || Nebraska: 59
(59-0 in 1981) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Current Streak''' || Nebraska: Won 3 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Longest Colorado Win Streak''' || 3 (1956â1958) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Longest Nebraska Win Streak''' || 18 (1968â1985) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''At Boulder''' || Nebraska leads 23-10-2 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''At Lincoln''' || Nebraska leads 26-8-0 |} The '''ColoradoâNebraska football rivalry''' was an American [[college football]] [[rivalry game|rivalry]] played by the [[Colorado Buffaloes football]] team of the [[University of Colorado]] and the [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football]] team of the [[University of Nebraska]]. The two teams first played in 1898, but the rivalry intensified during the 1980s, and was somewhat consolidated with the formation of the [[Big 12 Conference]], a development that placed the two universities in the same division of the Big 12 and ended Nebraska's annual matchup with [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]].http://espn.go.com/page2/s/rivalries/osumich_colneb.htmlhttp://www.gazette.com/articles/lincoln-89788-neb-nebraska.html The intensity of this rivalry was often disputed; while Colorado generally viewed Nebraska as its biggest rival, the feeling was not necessarily mutual as Nebraskans still generally viewed Oklahoma as its historically significant rivals even though they no longer played the Sooners every season. The game was traditionally played on the Friday afternoon following [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]], with the game being nationally televised on [[College Football on ABC|ABC]]. ==Series history== When [[Bill McCartney]] was hired by [[Colorado Buffaloes football|Colorado]] in 1982, he almost immediately designated [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]] as Colorado's primary rival, in an attempt to motivate his team.[http://www.huskerpedia.com/games/1982/05colorado.html HuskerPedia: Nebraska-Colorado Results and Recap 1982] Nebraska at that time was a perennial powerhouse program and had defeated Colorado fourteen times in a row, and McCartney wanted to use the eventual defeat of Nebraska as a measure of Colorado's success. Four years later, in 1986, Colorado got their first win since McCartney had arrived.[http://www.huskermax.com/games/1986/07colorado.html HuskerMax: Nebraska-Colorado Results and Recap 1986], a stunning 20-10 upset of #3 Nebraska. Colorado began to repeatedly threaten Nebraska in the late 1980s, following their 1986 upset win, and then surpassed the Huskers for the [[Big Eight Conference|Big 8]] Championship in 1989. Colorado traveled to Nebraska's [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] to again play for the Big 8 Championship in 1990, and the Buffaloes won 27â12 en route to their first [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|National Championship]]. The 19-19 tie in the 1991 matchup was the last tie recorded in the [[Big 8 conference]] and the last by both schools. To date they have played one contest decided in overtime, a 33-30 Nebraska victory in 1999. Historically the series was mostly one-sided, with the Huskers having won nearly three out of every four matchups. However, the last two decades had been very competitive with many matchups decided by a touchdown or less. Between 1996 and 2000, Nebraska won all five meetings by just a combined 15 points. The series was effectively disrupted by the [[2010–11 NCAA conference realignment]], when both teams left the Big 12. Colorado joined the [[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-12 Conference]] and Nebraska joined the [[Big Ten Conference]]. Nebraska will instead face the [[Iowa Hawkeyes football|Iowa Hawkeyes]] on the Friday following Thanksgiving, also on ABC; Colorado will revive a [[Colorado–Utah rivalry|decades-dormant rivalry]] with the [[Utah Utes football|Utah Utes]] the same day. == Game results == [http://www.huskermax.com/games/buffs.html HuskerMax: Nebraska-Colorado Series History] ''Colorado victories are shaded ââ gold.
